newsitem.title: BURUNDI: Tanzania delays U.S. plane in Burundi.
newsitem.headline: Tanzania delays U.S. plane in Burundi.

text.p: Tanzania's refusal to allow a U.S. airforce C-141 Starlifter to overfly its territory has delayed the plane's departure from Burundi, airport security officers and diplomats said on Wednesday.
More than five hours after landing, the transport plane was still parked at Bujumbura airport because of an argument over whether it was affected by regional sanctions against Burundi.
Fighting between government troops and Hutu rebels flared up a few miles to the east of the capital on Wednesday.
"It seems that Tanzania hasn't given clearance for the plane to take off," a senior airport security official told Reuters.
African states banned all air links with Burundi as part of sanctions imposed after a military coup on July 25.
A U.S. embassy spokesman in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital, denied the Starlifter was sent to war-torn Burundi to evacuate the few remaining U.S. citizens.
"This is not an evacuation. It is a routine embassy support flight," Louis Segesvary said.

But a Reuters correspondent at Bujumbura airport said 31 foreigners, including Americans, were in the departure lounge waiting to board the plane. Several said they were leaving Burundi because stepped-up fighting between the army and rebels had made it impossible to carry on their work.
U.S. diplomats in Burundi said negotiations to seek clearance from Tanzania to overfly the country en route to Nairobi were continuing.
